profileText: A Senator from New York; born in Bainbridge, Chenango County, N.Y., January 24, 1896; attended the public schools; during the First World War served overseas with the United States Army 1917-1919, discharged as first lieutenant, Infantry; graduated from Hamilton College, Clinton, N.Y., in 1920; engaged in the banking and insurance businesses in New York 1920-1930; member, New York State assembly 1930-1946, serving as minority leader in 1935, speaker in 1936, and majority leader 1937-1946; chairman of New York State Temporary Commission Against Discrimination 1944-1945; member, board of trustees of Hamilton College and Cornell University; dean of the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations 1945-1947; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1946, reelected in 1952, and served from January 3, 1947, to January 3, 1959; was not a candidate for renomination in 1958; unsuccessful candidate for election as Governor of New York in 1954; died in Norwich, N.Y., February 24, 1962; interment in Greenlawn Cemetery, Bainbridge, N.Y.

researchRecord.name: Correspondence in Blair Moody papers, 1928-1954; and Wilber M. Bruckner papers, 1877-1968.
In Harold Weston papers, 1916-1971; and Edward Corsi papers, 1918-1968 (partial restrictions).
Discussed in interview with Stanley Isaacs. Cornell University

1862-1958 (bulk 1933-1958). 268 cubic feet. Chiefly correspondence, memoranda, and other material from constituents, fellow legislators, executive departments, and the general public; speeches; press releases; clippings; and photographs related to his Senate career. Topics include appointments, legislation, committee hearings, education, federal agencies, commissions and departments, foreign affairs, labor and public welfare, international organizations, national defense and internal security, patronage, political campaigns, public utilities, social security, tariff and trade, taxation, transportation, and veterans' affairs. Also includes family, personal and business papers, and records pertaining to service in New York State Assembly.
In Richard Brown Scandrett papers, 1907-1966 (bulk 1907-1951); and "The Evolution of the Ives-Quinn Bill,'' by David A. Kapelman, 1972.
In Pauline Newman papers, 1903-1982; and Mary Elizabeth Drier papers, 1797-1963 (bulk 1897-1963).
In Greater Buffalo Industrial Union Council records, 1937-1958; and National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees general subject files, 1940-1970.
